item.title: [PI] Full Ingame HighScores with Saving
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

o 0 grr 0 o:

what u mean u mean i need add the highscores.java into to the client files?

You need to import it…
You see these:

import server.model.players.Client; import server.model.players.Player; import server.model.players.PlayerHandler; import server.model.players.PlayerSave;

They’re called imports. They allow you to use public methods from the said classes without having to redeclare the method.

A tip: IDE’s help a ton in this situation, they even give you solutions for import errors. You should try using one. Here’s a couple popular ones:

eclipse.org

Eclipse - The Eclipse Foundation open source community website.

Eclipse is probably best known as a Java IDE, but it is more: it is an IDE framework, a tools framework, an open source project, a community, an eco-system, and a foundation.


https://netbeans.org

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] Full Ingame HighScores with Saving
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Are you sure that’s the entire file? As there’s a missing end bracket.
From what I can tell. The class should work if you use this code:

[code=java]package server.util;

import server.model.players.HighScores;
import server.model.players.Client;
import server.model.players.Player;
import server.model.players.PlayerHandler;
import server.model.players.PlayerSave;
import server.Server;

public class ShutDownHook extends Thread {

@Override
public void run() {
	HighScores.save();
	System.out.println("Shutdown thread run.");
	for (Player p : PlayerHandler.players) {
		if (p != null) {
			PlayerSave.saveGame( ((Client) p) );
		}
	}
	System.out.println("Shutting down...");
}

}[/code]
What I did:
I added the package declaration to the top of the file.
I removed the brackets that were near HighScores.save(); and the end of the class (They were not needed).
I added the PlayerHandler and Player import, and also removed the Server import (It was no longer being used).
I converted the for loop to use a Player object instead of using an integer (You don’t need the index of the player in this scenario)
I changed the object being saved to the Player object (Since client extends player, you can convert the player object into a client object without any issues)

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] Full Ingame HighScores with Saving
item.dc:creator: @o_0_grr_0_o o 0 grr 0 o
item.description:
@o_0_grr_0_o wrote:

import server.model.players.HighScores;

import server.model.players.Client;
import server.model.players.PlayerSave;
import server.Server;

public class ShutDownHook extends Thread {

@Override
public void run() {
           	HighScores.save(); {
	System.out.println("Shutdown thread run.");
	for (int j = 0; j < Server.playerHandler.players.length; j++) {
		if (Server.playerHandler.players[j] != null) {
			Client c = (Client)Server.playerHandler.players[j];
			server.model.players.PlayerSave.saveGame(c);			
		}		
	}
	System.out.println("Shutting down...");
}

}

and thanks for help!

item.title: [PI] Full Ingame HighScores with Saving
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“o 0 grr 0 o, post:23, topic:456769”]Help please what is wrong?

http://gyazo.com/306fdfb6b9d1abee9216fe5e96642125[/quote]
You put a second package declaration into your code.

This is your error:

package server.util;// PERFECTLY FINE.
package server.util;// This causes an error!

You can only have one package declaration at the top of your class.

Read full topic
